Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Microstructure-Specific Machining Strategies for Bone

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The overarching research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to investigate the fundamental effect of bone microstructural components on its machining responses. In particular, the research will test the hypothesis that age/bone-type related variations seen in the microstructural components of bone have an influence on its critical machining responses such as surface integrity, cutting forces, tool-wear and chip morphology. The experimental studies will be aimed at linking the properties of bone microstructural phases to its machining responses. The microstructure-based finite element modeling study will be aimed at identifying age/bone-type-specific failure mechanisms encountered during machining. The educational objective of this CAREER award is to recruit, educate and develop the next generation of manufacturing professionals in the upstate New York region. The educational thrust areas include: 1) Developing a Lego-based, hands-on module to expose 6th-12th graders to micro-manufacturing technologies; 2) Developing an advanced manufacturing curriculum that promotes manufacturing education and careers to high-school girls; and 3) Enhancing the manufacturing education efforts at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.

The research findings will have implications for surgical procedures involving any form of bone machining. In particular, for total joint replacement surgeries the findings are likely to reduce patient recovery times and the probability of revision surgeries, both of which currently place a heavy economic burden on the healthcare system in the United States. This research will also result in product innovations in the multi-billion dollar market pertaining to bone surgery instrumentation and surgeon training platforms. The educational activities are geared towards addressing the current human resource crisis facing the nation in the area of advanced manufacturing. The educational module and curriculum being developed for the 6th-12th grade students, especially high school girls, has the potential to funnel K-12 students to manufacturing-related educational fields and careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The research activities conducted as part of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award have enabled a fundamental understanding of the effects of microstructural variations on the cutting responses of bovine cortical bone.  We have shown that cutting forces, tool wear, and bone surface damage are all influenced by the four key microstructural components of bovine cortical bone, namely, osteons, interstitial matrix, lamellar bone and woven bone. The underlying bone failure mechanisms are influenced both by the material properties of these microstructural components and their size-scale relative to the depth-of-cut of the tool. Fracture-dominated cutting (at depth-of-cuts greater than 70 microns) resulted in five distinct failure modes, namely, (i) osteon debonding, (ii) osteon fracture, (iii) interstitial matrix cracking, (iv) lamellar bone fracture and (v) woven bone fracture. Shear-dominated cutting (at depth-of-cuts less than 10 microns) did not exhibit such distinct microstructural influences on its underlying failure mechanisms.  For both modes of cutting, the experimental data showed a strong correlation between the cutting force and acoustic energy signals. While the cutting force data provides insight into the total energy consumed by the cutting process, the acoustic energy is specifically related to the creation of the fractured surface and chip breakage. The age-variant studies showed that cement-line fracture is the easiest failure to manifest in older bones.

On the modeling front, the work has resulted in three unique process-planning models. The microstructure-based finite element model was successfully shown to capture all the key failure mechanisms observed during fracture-dominant cutting. The research also resulted in the development of microstructure-based mechanistic models capable of predicting the cutting force and acoustic emission energy rates encountered in bone sawing. These three models present a significant advancement over the existing state of the literature that treats bone as a homogeneous material. The models are all characterized by innovative extractions of the properties required for implementing the microstructure-specific calculations. In addition to bovine cortical bone cutting the research has also successfully pursued applications involving dental caries and the manufacture of multi-scale vasculature-mimicking hydrogel structure with applications to bone/ligament tissue cultures.

 

BROADER IMPACT

In general, the research outcomes have implications for surgical procedures involving any form of bone machining.  Our findings have enabled a mapping between the key microstructural phases in cortical bone, and their respective machining characteristics. Such a mapping is currently nonexistent in the literature and would enable quantitative metrics for age/bone-type related microstructure classifications to aid surgical tool-path planning. The predictive capability of the novel machining models will allow for the selection of microstructure-specific machining strategies involving tool geometry, tool path, cutting velocities, and depth-of-cut that minimize damage inflicted on the bone. It will also aid the design of microstructure-specific surgery instrumentation and surgeon training platforms, a currently non-existent technology space.

The educational efforts on this CAREER award were geared towards addressing the human resource crisis facing the nation in the area of advanced manufacturing. The Lego-based educational modules and curriculum developed for the 6-12th grade students, including high-school girls, has the potential for becoming a national model to funnel K-12 students to manufacturing-related educational fields and careers. The research findings have also been integrated as part of multiple graduate and undergraduate courses at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, NY. In terms of human resource development, this project provided opportunities for the training and development of student researchers (1 MS, 4 PhD and 2 undergraduates) in the areas of bone characterization, micro-scale cutting processes and modeling techniques. The project has resulted in 1 MS thesis, 4 doctoral dissertations (2 published, 2 in-preparation), and 8 peer-reviewed manuscripts (2 published and 6 in-preparation). The pending manuscripts are expected to be finalized by June 2021.
